Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my phone buzzing with a calendar reminder: team meeting in ten minutes. As a colleague, I was expected to join, share updates, and show I was engaged, even if it was just a routine catch-up. The meeting would be recorded, but I knew my absence might be noticed. Just then, two travelers waved me down, their arms full of heavy suitcases. As a taxi driver, I was expected to help them load their bags and provide a smooth, professional ride—especially since they wanted to split the fare, which always took extra attention. My mind raced. If I focused on the meeting, I’d risk giving poor service and possibly losing a tip or a good review. But if I skipped the meeting, I might seem disengaged to my team. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between being a reliable colleague and a dependable driver, both roles demanding my full attention at the same time.
